SUBSECTION.NAME: Lexical Addressing
SUBSECTION.TEXT:
One of the most common optimizations performed by compilers is the optimization of
variable name
lookup. Our compiler, as we have implemented it so far, generates code that uses the
lookup-variable-value
lookup_symbol_value
operation of the evaluator machine. This searches for a
variable name
by comparing it with each
variable name
that is currently bound, working frame by frame outward through the runtime environment. This search can be expensive if the frames are deeply nested or if there are many
variables. names.
For example, consider the problem of looking up the value of x while evaluating the expression
(* x y z) x * y * z
in an application of the
procedure function
that is returned by
(let ((x 3) (y 4)) (lambda (a b c d e) (let ((y (* a b x)) (z (+ c d x))) (* x y z))))
((x, y) => (a, b, c, d, e) => ((y, z) => x * y * z)(a * b * x, c + d + x))(3, 4)
Since a let expression is just syntactic sugar for a
lambda
function declaration expression
combination, this expression is equivalent to
((lambda (x y) (lambda (a b c d e) ((lambda (y z) (* x y z)) (* a b x) (+ c d x)))) 3 4)
((x, y) => (a, b, c, d, e) => ((y, z) => x * y * z)(a * b * x, c + d + x))(3, 4)
Each time lookup-variable-value searches for x, it must determine that the symbol x is not eq? to y or z (in the first frame), nor to a, b, c, d, or e (in the second frame).
Each time lookup_symbol_value searches for x, it must determine that the string "x" is not equal to "y" or "z" (in the first frame), nor to "a", "b", "c", "d", or "e" (in the second frame).
We will assume, for the moment, that our programs do not use definethat variables are bound only with lambda.

compile-time environment One way for the compiler to produce code that uses lexical addressing is to maintain a data structure called a compile-time environment. This keeps track of which
variables names
will be at which positions in which frames in the runtime environment when a particular
variable-access name-access
operation is executed. The compile-time environment is a list of frames, each containing a list of
variables. names.
(There will of course be no values bound to the
variables, names,
since values are not computed at compile time.) The compile-time environment becomes an additional argument to compile and is passed along to each code generator. The top-level call to compile uses an empty compile-time environment. When
a lambda body
the body of a lambda expression
is compiled,
compile-lambda-body compile_lambda_body
extends the compile-time environment by a frame containing the
procedures
functions
parameters, so that the
sequence making up the
body is compiled with that extended environment.
Similarly when the body of a block is compiled, compile_block extends the compile-time environment by a frame containing the scanned-out local names of the body, so that the body is compiled with that extended environment. compiler for JavaScriptscanning out internal declarations

In cases where find-variable returns not-found (that is, where the variable is not in the compile-time environment), you should have the code generators use the evaluator operations, as before, to search for the binding. (The only place a variable that is not found at compile time can be is in the global environment, which is part of the runtime environment but is not part of the compile-time environment.Lexical addresses cannot be used to access variables in the global environment, because these names can be defined and redefined interactively at any time. With internal definitions scanned out, as in exercise, the only definitions the compiler sees are those at top level, which act on the global environment. Compilation of a definition does not cause the defined name to be entered in the compile-time environment. Thus, if you wish, you may have the evaluator operations looks directly in the global environment, which can be obtained with the operation (opget-global-environment), instead of having them search the whole runtime environment found in env.)
This is not possible in an interactive system that keeps extending the program environment. Note the new driver_loop in and the same idea recurring in compile_and_go in .
In cases where find_symbol returns "not found" (that is, where the symbol is not in the compile-time environment), we can safely raise a compile-time error. Because we use lexical scoping for all names, it is not possible for a name to be found at runtime, that was not found at compile-time. (This would not be the case if we used dynamic scoping where the surrounding environment for a name is determined by its use, not its definition.)

JAVASCRIPT.EXERCISE: constant (in JavaScript)detecting assignment to In JavaScript, an attempt to assign to a name that is declared as a constant leads to an error. Exercise shows how to detect such errors at run time. With the techniques presented in this section, we can detect these errors at compile time and avoid running a program that tries to assign to a constant. For this purpose, extend the functions compile_lambda_body and compile_block to record whether a name is declared as a variable (using let or as a parameter), or as a constant (using const) in the compile-time environment. Modify compile_assignment to generate an appropriate error when it detects an assignment to a constant.

compiler for JavaScriptopen coding of primitives open coding of primitives compile-time environmentopen coding and We can apply the idea of the previous exercise to the technique of open coding in exercise: For this, our compile-time environment can store for many constants what types of values they will refer to at run time, by looking at their value expressions. For example, in the scope where const x = 42 appears, we know that x will always refer to a number. Or the number 42, to be precise. However reasoning about a names type is often a useful abstraction; for example adding a number to a string is always as error, no matter what the values are of the number and the string.
Similarly, for each scope, we can identify at compile time names that will always refer to a compound function object at run time, and store this information in the compile-time environment. Use such an extended compile-time environment in the compilation of function applications to move the test if a function is primitive or compound to compile time where possible. This will allow you to produce much simpler object code for the cases where this property can be determined, as you will only need the code in either the primitive branch or the compiled branch in compile_function_call.
